awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Affordable Onsite Wastewater Treatment Solution
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide homeowners with an affordable on-site wastewater treatment solution. Hawaii’s coral reefs are under threat from products of hundreds of thousands of onsite treatment systems across the state seeping into the groundwater and eventually reaching the coastal ecosystem. The proposed onsite wastewater treatment technology could will address this with wide-ranging environmental benefits. The State of Hawaii has legislated the replacement of residential cesspools by 2050 in order to reduce the pollution in streams and the ocean. Unfortunately, upgrade costs are so high that 90% of Hawaiian cesspool owners can’t afford the upgrade. The proposed technology can reduce the cost of upgrades by 5-10x. While the initial application will be in Hawaii, the technology will have national applicability.  

The proposed system uses an algal bacterial biofilm to passively aerate wastewater recirculated from a septic tank to conduct nitrifying, denitrifying, and heterotrophic operations. Previous investigations into abPBR use for onsite treatment have shown the capacity for high nutrient and BOD removal, but only with active maintenance and pumped recirculation.  This project proposes a novel system with this performance but without high maintenance or energy demands. A novel convection-based passive recirculation process will be the primary focus of this study, with a focus on determining how experimentally determined passive recirculation rates and internal temperatures align with computational models, as well as standards for on-site residential wastewater treatment systems. The project will also explore susceptibility to and impact of disrupted recirculation due to gases coming out of solution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this Phase I SBIR grant, WaiHome investigated the feasibility of its patent-pending Passive ATU (PATU) for onsite wastewater treatment. The State of Hawaii has recently legislated the replacement of an estimated 88,000 residential cesspools by 2050. Unfortunately, a DOH sponsored study found that 97% of homeowners couldn't afford to do so, even with traditional septic systems, the most affordable existing solution. Further, through county-level property data, WaiHome determined that existing spatial and geological conditions made septic system upgrades impossible for 55% of cesspool owners. The PATU has the potential to allow homeowners to comply with the incoming mandate without the complex and bulky underground onsite treatment systems that are so expensive to install and maintain in Hawaii. 

The PATU is a form of algal-biofilm photobioreactor (abPBR). AbPBR's have been tested at the lab scale and implemented in a number of centralized wastewater treatment applications but have yet to be adapted for residential use. The PATU has been designed to be similar in size and shape to a solar hot water heater to allow for ground or roof mounted integration into small properties. Under this NSF SBIR Phase I grant, the PATU was built and tested in a number of configurations until it reliably produced effluent that came close to meeting stringent NSF 245 water quality standards. 

Initial testing of the PATU as a septic tank add-on demonstrated that the unit had difficulty passively recirculating and treating a large enough fraction of the septic volume while still maintaining a hospitable environment for microbes. Further, the affordability concerns of septic systems were only compounded with the addition of the PATU as an additional treatment step. As a result, WaiHome pivoted its process design to pair the PATU with commercially available wastewater solid composters. These systems, either in the form of individual composting toilets or central household-scale composters, remove the bulk of solids from the toilet blackwater stream but produce an ammonia and organic rich leachate. This leachate and the remaining untreated kitchen blackwater mean homeowners with composting systems are still required to install a septic system at significant expense. WaiHome permitted and tested a novel configuration in which its PATU was installed in lieu of a septic tank to treat composter leachate along with the remaining household wastewater from a one-person tiny house. Over a two-month period, this configuration produced a treated effluent with just 26 mg/L of biological oxygen demand (BOD) and 11.3 mg/L of total suspended solids (TSS) remaining and 76% of total nitrogen removed. With just a 1 mg/L improvement in effluent BOD, the composter/PATU treatment train will meet NSF 245 standards for discharge to sensitive receiving environments at a fraction of the cost of traditional systems.

Beyond WaiHome's mission to improve access to sanitation in rural American communities, the company is actively engaged in technical workforce education and development. During this Phase I research effort, WaiHome collaborated with a consortium of Hawaiian community colleges and a local non-profit to bring in $2M in federal grants to develop a training program for cesspool replacement. Additionally, WaiHome offered a wastewater reclamation high-school course through the local Pathway-to-Purpose program. To continue to support local workforce development, WaiHome has begun developing relationships with American wastewater treatment product manufacturers in order to form a cohesive licensing and production strategy for manufacturing WaiHome's products in America.
